As a Modifier, Thor's damaged hair should have been good as new in no time. Because she overtaxed her Divine Power, however, she'd just have to wait for her hair to grow back in its own time.
Thor's hair grew very quickly. When she could get her hair into two braids again, Odin took out the first pair of hair ties from the box. "That's long enough"—Though Thor thought this, her hair had other plans. When it got a bit longer, Odin gave her another pair of hair ties. Before long, Thor was once again beset with that particular annoyance that came with her long hair. Unwilling to settle for this, Thor snipped off her lengthy braids in a fury. But she woke up the next day only to find herself entangled in her long copper hair again. "It's no use, your hair's as long as it always is." Gesturing at Thor's hair, Odin took out the last pair of hair ties from the box. She twisted Thor's hair into thick braids to keep them from getting in the way during battle.
"It's exactly the same." Thor let out a sigh as she looked at her reflection in the mirror. But... what does that mean? Exactly the same as what? She couldn't say for sure.
Looking at her "restored" hair, Thor remembers her tattered cape. Her singed hair could grow back on its own, but the same couldn't be said of her torn cape. She stowed away the old cape that went into battle with her in the Source Layer, replacing it with a newer, more intact one.
The new cape was made of a special material that, though light-weight, was impervious to the damage wrought by Thor's thunder. But maybe it was just too light, or maybe because it hindered her thunder as a result, but Thor just never felt that it fit her quite right. In the end, she couldn't help but take out that old, unwieldy, and tattered cape again. Though drab and full of holes, those marks all served as proof of her previous battles, and that heavy past was anything but a burden to her.
Before heading out the door, Thor glances at herself in the mirror. Seeing those long braids and that old cape, she's struck by an intense feeling of déjà vu stretching out from a distant past. With it comes gloom, pain, and retreat... Strange images flood her mind—scenes so lifelike, it's like she experienced them herself. She immediately stamps out these thoughts.
After all, she can't see the future like Odin can. Those tragic scenes could be a forgotten past, or even dreams—but they certainly aren't her future.
1028.task_desc: In Main Story 12-1-2: The Returning Two (Normal), use Tremblestrike at least 1 time during the battle and clear the stage.

1139.name: Drowning
1139.story:
She reaches out her hand. The water returns the gesture in kind, flowing with the same force. The light of the day is falling, just like she is.
Everything on the shore is receding.
If she could just get a little closer, she could see that crystal glowing with a wonderful blue light. Just a little closer.
Her surroundings get colder and colder. It must be an ice crystal.
But before she can clearly make out its shape, her body is already too weak to move.
The blue of the endless expanse is clear and pure. She surrenders her body to the breathing of the current, letting Mother Ocean rock her in her invisible cradle. Water envelops her from all sides as this crystal-clear medium delivers one last ray of sun from the ocean's surface to her eyes. Then, the light dims—but not because the sun has set.
A beluga whale sweeps over her head.
It's singing. The melody in the water flows into her heart, which reverberates with the song. Amid this vibrating resonance, she seems to hear this marvelous, snow-white creature speaking to her.
"What are you doing here?" 
Wanting to answer but unable to speak, she speaks with her heart instead: "It's so beautiful here, I just couldn't help but swim down..."
The beluga is silent, as if waiting for her to ask for its help.
"Sorry, but I think I'm lost. Could you tell me how to get back?" 
"Come with me." 
The beluga seems to say something else as well, but by then her headband has come loose, covering her ears and strangling her heart...
The temperature calls her consciousness back to her body. Poseidon's body stirs and is answered by soft bedding.
Shu is sitting beside the bed. When she sees that Poseidon is awake, she asks her where she went, what she was doing, and why she fainted on the shore all of a sudden.
Poseidon thinks for a moment, then says that she seems to have had a very long dream. In her dream, a school of fish made a path for her and a beluga whale carried her up to the water's surface.
Shu considers this, then says that perhaps the current just happened to carry her to shore, or a passing boat found her, or maybe she simply hadn't been to such depths before. A beluga whale and a school of fish saving a drowned girl... That sort of reverie could only happen in a work of fantasy. Honestly, it's just not... logical.
Seeing how seriously Shu is taking this, Poseidon just smiles without saying anything more.
Let's just say it was a dream then.
1139.task_desc: In Main Story 4-12: Strongest Creation (Normal), defeat Kusherfang with Arctic Abyss - Poseidon alone, use Matter Frozen at least 1 time during the battle, and clear the stage.

1184.name: Old Armor
1184.story:
It's like a robot.
The external structure is making the joints stiff and jerky. Verthandi's arms move clumsily, like she's operating a machine lever.
On an ordinary, rainy afternoon many years ago, Verthandi was sitting by the window and flipping through a storybook when she saw a picture of a knight carrying himself with an air of dignity. Perhaps she didn't realize then that, one day, she too would be clad in armor with a sword and shield in her hands.
But everything has a price—This complex, exquisite armor she'd worked so hard to put on just isn't fitting right somewhere on her arms. Whenever she bends them, the edges of the armor pinch her skin. Not enough to draw blood, but it still delivers a sharp twinge. Verthandi reflexively tries to break it off, but the metallic curvature doesn't budge.
She endures this vague discomfort through one training session after another until the indentations are nearly engraved into her arms and she's gotten used to it.
It's not that she hasn't considered sending the armor back for adjustments—rather, it's only when she finds her movements hindered in the heat of battle that it even occurs to her. Once the battle is over, she promptly forgets, thus missing each opportunity she gets to resolve the issue. When all is said and done, the problem isn't bad enough to get in the way of victory whatsoever.
That is, until a flying chunk of rock comes hurtling toward her and she's unable to summon her shield in time. Meanwhile, there are countless people she wants to protect behind her.
She knows her metal armor is sturdy—sturdy enough to smash the rock.
Verthandi raises her arm. When she raises her arms to block the massive stone, perhaps she hasn't realized yet that, one day, she'd face a mountain on the verge of collapse.
The force of the impact embeds the edges of the armor into her skin, sending excruciating pain through her arms.
The next time she dons this marred armor, she'll know that the armguards were bent to perfection by that blow.
1184.task_desc: In Main Story 15-2-7: Even When Ground to Dust (Normal), clear the stage again.

1033.name: Unknown Data
1033.story:
It's late at night, and in the dim laboratory, Heimdall is conducting her 21st round of data validation.
The terminal screen casts a blue light on her face as data and theories orbit and tangle in her head, like a spiraling ladder bringing her ever closer to her objective.
The Rubik's cube of data before her eyes is an auxiliary Visbane analysis tool that's about to be integrated into the Mimir system. The sheer volume of data calculation and preparation alone that went into this experiment before its launch made it 95% controllable. From there, the theoretical testing only increases its accuracy slightly—Many would dismiss Heimdall's rigor as paranoia bordering on obsession.
"If there really is a problem, it'll be borne out in the practical phase. Why waste all this time doing such exhaustive theoretical testing?" 
As a matter of fact, she too was once driven by such thinking to rush the newly developed Mimir into service.
But she had no way to control the path of Mimir's self-directed learning, and his mind turned out to be wildly different from the AI assistant she'd envisioned. Everything had run counter to her expectations.
"Mimir's just a little grumpy. He's still helped us plenty in battle." 
While this feedback was far from negative, Heimdall took it to be just another form of consolation.
This outcome was due to nothing more than chance—Like a lonesome boat sailing on a sea of unknowns, there was no telling if the next second could be its last above the surface.
What if this wasn't an auxiliary system, but more of an important combat tool?
And who will pay the price for this "unknown" when the time comes? When this "unknown" puts her friends in danger, will she still be able to see it as a simple experimental error then?
After this, she halted all her ongoing experiments and turned her efforts to making endless theoretical calculations.
Putting all theoretical possibilities to the test before conducting any experiment, she'll try to eliminate all "unknowns" to the best of her ability.
Only after achieving clarity in every aspect will she progress an experiment to the subsequent phase, followed by another round of endless argumentation and calculation, and so the cycle continues.
The clattering of her keystrokes gets faster and faster—She's already spent an entire day working to test the final theoretical possibility.
Such a task has always been made tedious by the repetition and futility of the effort required, and not even Heimdall is impervious to its grating effects.
But whenever she thinks of the price of the "unknown," her restless mind will settle down again, allowing her to calmly review the data report in her hand and use all the knowledge at her disposal to find any errors within it.
The 22nd round of data validation begins, and finally, the data is showing a slight change. Heimdall exhales deeply—She finally has an explanation for that nagging feeling she had before as well.
"So, it was an error caused by neglecting to take environmental factors into account during the data collection... I'd better run another check." 
As the data reports keep piling up, the haze over that sea of unknowns is gradually dispersed by a beacon of data and theory.
The first rays of dawn shine into the dim laboratory, announcing that Heimdall's work is now finished. She's eliminated every conceivable uncontrollable factor.
The exhaustion she'd been keeping at bay at last washing over her, she leans over the table with a satisfied smile—It's time to rest.
1033.task_desc: In Main Story 4-12: Strongest Creation (Normal), defeat Kusherfang with Enlightening - Heimdall alone, use Lightrealm Ultimate or Gensrealm Ultimate at least 1 time during the battle, and clear the stage.

1042.name: Gift
1042.story:
Ever since she created Mintha and Leuce, Hades has protected them as jealously as though they were her sisters. And, to satisfy her sisters' curiosity, she's even built them a small library.
It's an early winter's morning, and the feel of the chill wind against Hade's face removes any last traces of sleepiness. Hades looks out of the window as she thinks about the day's schedule. Luckily, the association is quiet at the moment and she has some free time.
Mintha and Leuce aren't in the aquarium. Although their mistress has never restricted their movements, their frequent excursions outside these past few days have piqued her curiosity.
They don't return until the sun has fully risen in the sky.
"Good morning, Lady Hades." The puppets bow at her, their hands behind their backs.
"Good morning Mintha, Leuce." It's obvious that they're hiding something behind their backs, but Hades waits for them to explain by themselves.
"Lady Hades, you once said that we can study whatever it is that interests us. And I read that presenting gifts is a way of showing appreciation," Mintha says. From behind their backs, they bring out a beautifully wrapped box.
"I also helped choose it, Lady Hades," Leuce adds. 
The box contains a pair of lavender earrings. There's a note too – "Thank you for everything you've done for us, Lady Hades." 
The puppets look at her with their blue eyes as deep and as clear as lakes, as countless emotions ripple through them – excitement, expectation, reverence... Hades can read all this as clear as day, and her heart swells.
"What's wrong, Lady Hades? Don't you like them?" they ask in unison upon seeing her failure to react.
"Leuce, Leuce, look! Lady Hades is smiling!" 
It's as though the warm embrace of the summer sun has chased away the winter cold, and the corners of Hades' mouth turn upward uncontrollably.
She carefully removes the earrings from the box like they're fragile treasures. She doesn't want to drop them, nor does she want to grip them so tight they break.
"Oh, they're beautiful... So what do you think I should get you in return?" Hades puts on her new earrings and affectionately strokes the puppets' heads.
"In return?" 
"Oh yes, I remember reading that it's polite to give a gift in return when you receive one." 
When Mintha says this, Leuce tilts her head in thought.
"Lady Hades, I would like to learn more things." 
"Me too. That way, we'll be able to help you out more." 
Hades has long been prepared to agree to any request the puppets make, but this exceeds even her expectations. It's like vintage wine that continues to pour even when the glass is full.
"Please, Lady Hades!" Mintha and Leuce both grab her hand, and she notices how warm their cold synthetic skin is.
"I think... we're going to need a bigger library!"
1042.task_desc: In Main Story 11-18 (Normal) "All-Out Curtain Call", use Puppet Master - Hades as team leader, and clear the stage.

1024.name: Farewell
1024.story:
My adoptive father was a police officer. He'd sometimes talk to me about his important cases, and whenever he talked about big ones that hadn't been solved, he always spoke with determination and drive. Then, after realizing that he'd said too much, he'd suddenly go back to his usual kind and caring self. You can really see the integrity in a person like that, and there's no one that I admired more.
I didn't know exactly what my father did at first. For a long time, I just thought he was "keeping the peace." During the holidays, my father would often take me out for dinner with his friends. We usually sat in a small place outside while his friends made small talk, and sometimes, they'd throw a question or two in my direction, like what I wanted to be when I grew up. When I said that I wanted to be a police officer like my father, they went quiet for a minute, then burst out laughing. The man next to me patted me on the back and they left it there.
My father was always busy with work, and for my whole time at school, he only picked me up a handful of times. Those were the only days when I didn't have to spend ages waiting at the bus stop. There was a flower shop across the road from my school, and every time my father came to get me, he'd stop in there for a bunch of lilies. I never understood why such white flowers would be wrapped up in such dark paper, but my father never explained. Back then, he still had this warmth emanating from inside him, but there was also a hint of sadness which I couldn't quite grasp.
At dinner, an uncle once asked my father when he would build the garden he'd talked about putting in front of the house. It sounded like something my father had said after a few drinks, and he politely changed the subject, but when I looked at the bouquets of flowers he'd bought, I thought it wouldn't be too long before there could be a whole field of them outside our front door. I don't really like flowers, but they'd be much better than the bare soil.
I never did see the new garden, nor did I see the man who'd laughed and patted me on the back. I asked my father where he was, and he told me the truth. He said that the man had died, and I could sense my father's grief as clearly as the lilies that he held in his hands.
That's how I found out that a bouquet of flowers could be used as an offering when someone died, and I realized why everyone had gone silent when I said I wanted to be a police officer like my father.
...
They brought news of my father's death, saying that he'd been involved in a big smuggling operation in Rostach and had died a hero. I could tell they were lying, but I didn't argue. It was up to me to find the hard truth on my own.
The flower shop opposite my school had closed down, and my father's car would never be there to pick me up again. I took a bus ride around the whole city before I finally managed to buy a bunch of lilies.
The Egregious Crimes Department. I retraced my father's steps and that's where I ended up.
When they heard the news of my father's death, they gave me his name tag, "Jackal." That became my code name from that day forward.
1024.task_desc: Use Spirit Guide at least one time in The Jackal's Choice stage of the Father, Son, Duel - Part I side story, and complete the stage.

1094.name: The Bird Box
1094.story:
The old gun blasted, and the face of the woman who had just been begging for mercy suddenly shattered, the cracks spreading like a spider web across her entire face, then breaking apart like a jigsaw puzzle that had been put together wrong. Beneath the cracks, the disjointed body of a Visbane was revealed.
A string of incorrect code began to squirm, and sharp objects drawn from the darkness with both malice and madness came to slash down the young woman's delicate face.
The black coffin quickly transformed and rushed to the monster before it could fully mutate. Like a heavy shield, it forced the attacking monster back into a corner.
"The new defense system works, Miss Hel."
The woman nodded, reactivated her Divine Grace, and pointed the gun at the monster. Curling flames lit up the room, and dark purple energy poured out, engulfing the monster from head to toe.
Then, everything went quiet, and the small woman waved her arms in her sleeves, holding her Access Key tightly in her hands. She strained her little legs slightly, and sat herself up on the side of the heavy, black coffin.
People who made trouble for no reason, people who said the vilest things, and people who begged for their lives. Before they turned into monsters, all of these people, without exception, would glare at Hel with those bloodshot eyes full of hate.
...
But scenes like this were an everyday occurrence for girls like her dealing with the Encroacher Types.
The cold, empty streets were covered with a white fog, and the chiming of a distant church sounded like a death knell.
She knew that those things could no longer be considered human, but the cold road back from doing her job still felt exceptionally bitter. Hel crossed her arms in her sleeves, trying to ease the fatigue of battle with their warmth.
She should have left to find her next target, but something made her turn her head. Behind her, a little girl was having her memories erased... a picture of the young woman held in her hands.
Maybe she was lucky to forget all those painful memories... but she had to forget all the past joys as well, as if nothing had happened in the first place.
Flesh and blood, feelings, memories... The darkness in the world swallowed everything it touched.
And if the darkness was going to swallow everything, if everything was soon to be lost anyway, then what should they do?
"Never have anything to start with." That used to be her answer, but since arriving at Aether Gazer, Hel couldn't help feeling that there was a better answer to be found.
Back from her duties, Hel sat by the window, replaying the question in her mind as she started taking the small box from Ganglati.
"What's on your mind, Miss Hel?"
"Ganglati, is it better to never have something in the first place, if you're just going to lose it anyway?"
"I'm sorry, but I'm just an ordinary Access Key interface, so I'm not really capable of answering such a complex question. That said, I'm better at understanding people than most, and my guess is that that "something" is something you need right now."
Somewhere to the side of Ganglati, a dark square opened and a small, black box popped out.
Ignoring the black coffin as it continued mumbling proudly to itself, Hel's pale hands clutched the box in her arms and slowly opened it.
This is where she stored the things that were important to her or that she found beautiful, things like her butterfly, her cat toy, her crystal, and more.
The cheap, man-made crystal reflected the clear moonlight, the butterfly hairpin that hadn't been worn for a long time sat quietly next to it, and now that it was fixed, the black cat had stopped shaking. When she held it in her arms, Hel felt just a bit warmer.
Under the dark night sky, the young woman's daily duties were about to start once more.
